Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Integrated In Silico and Non-Target Analytical Framework for High Throughput Prioritization of Bioactive Transformation Products
Award.AbstractNarration:
Today, water resources are threatened by a complex mixture of chemical pollutants, many of which are poorly removed by traditional water and wastewater treatment technologies. These include potent pharmaceutical classes including synthetic steroids, whose bioactivity can persist in the environment despite their transformation through natural and engineered processes. In this project funded by the Environmental Chemical Sciences Program of the Chemistry Division at the National Science Foundation, a collaborative team of researchers at the University of Iowa, University of Washington at Tacoma and Seattle, University of California at San Diego, and Stony Brook University develops a predictive framework to help catalyze more robust water regulations and improved chemical risk assessment. Ultimately, outcomes of this project moves society toward more safe and sustainable water supplies, particularly as society becomes more reliant on reuse of treated wastewater to bridge the widening gap in supply and demand. The broader impacts of this work include advancing undergraduate education by enabling the participation of under-represented groups in research activities, integrating modern computational tools into student learning, and promoting scientific literacy in non-technical audiences through general education coursework development.

This work represents a new paradigm in water quality management. Focusing on a widely utilized abiotic treatment process, chlorination, and ubiquitous but understudied pollutant classes, potent synthetic progestins and glucocorticoids, this project will develop a high-throughput framework built upon computational and experimental methods for the a priori prediction of high risk, bioactive transformation products. This approach integrates (i) theoretical calculations to identify probable chlorination products using descriptors for both parent (partial charges, oxidation potentials) and likely product (thermodynamic stability) species. (ii) Potential product species are prioritized based on bioactivity (i.e., risk) using high throughput virtual ligand screening. Once identified, formation and yield of high risk products are evaluated (iii) in bench-scale experiments across a range of chlorination conditions and (iv) via high resolution mass spectrometric detection in wastewaters and receiving waters. Research outcomes ensures that when emerging pollutant classes are inevitably regulated, a more holistic approach is available that also addresses risks posed by their bioactive products. This collaborative project provides transdisciplinary training of 2 graduate students, 2 postdocs, and several undergraduates at the interface of environmental chemistry, computational chemistry, and biochemistry.

POR.DRECONTENT:
United States water quality is harmed by the large numbers of potential chemical contaminants we discharge. Relative to the many chemicals present in water, only a few of these chemicals are regulated because they are detected in water or harm the health of humans or the environment. However, many types of chemicals are widely used in medicine and agriculture, or discharged by humans, and these chemicals require more screening for possible negative impacts on water and the environment. One special concern is that many known chemical pollutants can degrade in the environment through natural (for example, breakdown in sunlight) or engineered (for example, water treatment) processes to produce new, unknown chemicals. These so-called “transformation products” can also be harmful, but they are difficult to study, and they often are not included when risk assessments are used to develop regulations for water resource protection. Accordingly, we do not always know how to manage them effectively.

This collaborative research project between the University of Iowa, the University of Washington, Stony Brook University and the University of California at San Diego was designed to study these transformation products. We investigated better ways to identify the formation of high-risk transformation products from “parent” chemicals like steroid pharmaceuticals, insecticides and fungicides used in agriculture, and industrial chemicals. Using complementary computational and laboratory experimental tools, the research team identified several different systems or chemicals where transformation products that formed proved to be of higher risk for harm to humans or ecosystems. For example, when natural and synthetic steroids react with chlorine during disinfection of water and wastewater, we identified several chemical products that retain unique or even greater biological activity than the chemical from which they were formed. We also produced new computational approaches to better predict what transformation products might form during chlorination and which transformation products are most likely to harm human health and the environment. We detected some of these transformation products in wastewater effluents that are discharged into rivers and estimated which types of biological pathways they might affect. We also identified a highly toxic transformation product that formed from industrial chemicals widely used in tires. This toxic chemical is likely harming salmon in the Pacific Northwest where they are exposed to runoff from busy roads.

The work is innovative for its integrated approach of using both computational and experimental approaches to focus on transformation products and produce tools that can be used to better estimate and manage risks from these kinds of chemical contaminants.  The work also trained several graduate and undergraduate researchers in a highly interdisciplinary and collaborative research environment. Ultimately, this work will move society toward higher quality and more sustainable water resources, with research outputs that will help catalyze more robust treatment processes, make stronger water regulations, and improve chemical risk assessments. It also helps us to understand which chemicals are especially risky so that we can design better and more environmentally friendly consumer products.
